In Fig. 7, an example of the fuzzy output with a simple input (0.2,0.5,0.8)0.20.50.8(0.2,0.5,0.8) is presented.
Note that the fuzzy input variables are normalized according to (21) for ease of analysis.
Based on Fig. 4, we find that the normalized fuzzy input of the client (0.2,0.5,0.8)0.20.50.8(0.2,0.5,0.8) indicates that the channel quality is â€˜weakâ€™, the data quantity is â€˜averageâ€™ and the local model is â€˜staleâ€™.
Hence, according to rule 24 in Table I, the corresponding fuzzy output is â€˜averageâ€™, and then the normalized output can be obtained from the x-axis value in Fig. 7.
For other more complicated cases with multiple fuzzy rules, the final normalized output is obtained through the COG method, as shown in (22).

In this part, abundant of simulations are conducted to verify the superior performance of our proposed schemes.
A square area with side length of 500 meters is considered in our simulation, and the cloud server is located at its center.
We considered 4 edge servers which are deployed at the midpoints of the lines connecting the four corners of the square to the cloud server, serving 64 randomly distributed clients.
We set the number of associated clients for each edge server Nmsubscriptğ‘ğ‘šN_{m} as 4 considering the designing complexity of the NOMA receiver.
The HFL algorithm is used for the classification task using the MNIST dataset.
We consider two data distribution scenarios in our simulation, including the independent and identically distributed (IID) data distribution and the non-IID data distribution.
Specifically, for the former, the data distribution is the same among all clients, while in the non-IID scenario, different types of data labels are hold by different clients [39].
We present other simulation parameters in Table II.
